A Preview of

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Three Overarching Goals
1.
Give you a basic understanding of how the ocean 
works - geologically, physically, biologically and 
chemically.  
2.
Raise your awareness of an array of human threats 
to the ocean.
 
3.
Inspire you to raise your voice and contribute to 
making a better world!!!

© 2023 Bruce Monger
We Begin With The 
Fundamentals of How The 
Ocean Works
Ocean Waves 
Big Bang, Origin of Stars, 
 
Earth, Moon & Oceans
Marine Geology
Ocean Food Webs
Ocean Tides
Ocean Chemistry
Ocean Currents

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Purpose of The Lectures on 
Fundamentals
• Deliver basic ocean science. 
• Show that we are not the center 
of the universe. 
• Show that the ocean is an 
important component in earths 
life support system.
Ocean Waves 
Big Bang, Origin of Stars, 
 
Earth, Moon & Oceans
Marine Geology

Ocean Currents
Ocean Tides

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The ocean has absorbed 
40%
 of all the 
anthropogenic CO
2
 we have emitted 
since the beginning of the industrial era.
Ocean Uptake of Anthropogenic CO
2
https://oceanographicmagazine.com/news/ocean-carbon-sink-rate/#:~:text=Approximately 40% of the carbon,taken up by the ocean.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Ocean Uptake of Anthropogenic 
Heat Imbalance
The ocean have taken up 
93%
 of the 
excess heat energy that has accumulated 
in the earth system because of 
anthropogenic greenhouse gases.
https://skepticalscience.com/Search-For-Missing-Heat-Confirms-More-Global-Warming-In-The-Pipeline-.html

© 2023 Bruce Monger
When ocean currents change, they modify the sea 
surface temperature underlying the atmosphere that, 
in turn, can drive anomalies in wind patterns, weather 
and climate across the planet. 
The Ocean Can Alter Climatic Patterns 
(Droughts and Floods) Around the World

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Ocean Heat Energy Influences 
the Strength of Hurricanes
The top 3 meters of the ocean contains 
the equivalent amount of heat energy as 
the entire atmosphere overlying the ocean.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Great 
Conveyor Belt Circulation
 of 
the global ocean moves heat away the 
equator and toward the poles and 
moderates latitudinal gradients in surface 
temperatures. 
Global Ocean Heat 
Transport

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The the ocean accounts for half of total 
global photosynthesis and, therefore, half 
the oxygen produced each year. 
You owe a thank you to the ocean for 
every other breath you take!
Oxygen Production by Ocean 
Phytoplankton

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1 in 5 people on the planet depend 
on fish as their primary source of 
protein
Food Production
 |  4
OBJECTIVES AND APPROACH 
Objectives
!
is report synthesizes current understanding of 
the contributions of capture 
"
sheries to food and 
nutrition security and explores drivers of those 
contributions. It addresses three overarching 
questions: (1) What contributions do capture 
"
sheries 
make to food and nutrition security? (2) What is the 
current policy dialogue regarding the links between 
capture 
"
sheries and food and nutrition security? (3) 
What data are available to inform research and policy 
development to support the contributions of capture 
"
sheries to food and nutrition security?
!
e report addresses these questions with the aim of 
situating dialogue squarely within the science-policy 
interface. 
!
e overall goal is to provide a foundation 
of knowledge to inform the trajectory of research, 
policy, and practice that supports the role of capture 
"
sheries in achieving sustainable development goals 
(SDGs) to end poverty (SDG1) and hunger (SDG2).
Scope
Both capture 
"
sheries and aquaculture are 
important food production systems that can make 
complementary contributions to food and nutrition 
security. 
!
e primary focus of this report is on 
"
sheries, which provide diverse forms of nutrition 
to a wide range of people and which face signi
"
cant 
threats. 
!
is focus addresses SDG14 of the United 
Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development: 
to “conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas 
and marine resources for sustainable development” 
as the “increasingly adverse impacts of climate 
change (including ocean acidi
"
cation), over
"
shing 
and marine pollution are jeopardizing recent gains 
in protecting portions of the world’s oceans” (UN 
2015b; 2017, 15). Just as importantly, the emphasis on 
capture 
"
sheries acknowledges the unique threats to 
inland 
"
sheries, including invasive species, pollution 
from agricultural runo
#
, and competition with other

"
sheries, including invasive species, pollution 
from agricultural runo
#
, and competition with other 
freshwater uses such as hydropower, irrigation, and 
aquaculture (Youn et al. 2014).
However, fully removing aquaculture from 
discussions of capture 
"
sheries is impossible. First, 
aquaculture in
$
uences the dynamics of capture 
"
sheries in multiple ways. Second, some key data 
and research do not di
#
erentiate between farmed 
and captured 
"
sh. Finally, despite the guidance 
provided by the de
"
nitions included in the glossary 
of this report, the distinction between aquaculture

Coral Reefs
 and 
Mangroves
 
provide coastal protection from 
storm surges  
Coral Reefs also provide food and 
biodiversity and a source of new 
medicines. 
Mangroves also provide water 
filtration of pollutants before 
waters enter to ocean
Coastal Protection
https://allislandscommittee.wordpress.com/tag/coastal-protection/

2
 
concentration is increasing by

Limiting global warming to 
1.5 °C
 is the goal we aspire 
to attain.

Human civilization developed during
 
a period of remarkably stable 
climate that began 10,000 years ago.  


We now risk leaving that stability behind with human-caused 
climate change.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geologic_temperature_record

evolved

Sea Level Rise


1/4 meter average to date
With Business as Usual 
emissions, sea level is expected 
to reach 
1-Meter
 by the end of 
the century.


But some models predict this 
rise could be reached in 30 
years.
https://www.globalchange.gov/browse/indicators/global-sea-level-rise

Ocean Acidification
1.
Within decades
 polar 
oceans will be corrosive to 
unprotected calcareous 
shells of marine organisms


2.
Within decades
 
tropical coral 
reef
 growth will be hampered 
or stopped altogether.
26% increase in ocean acidity

Prospect for Action on Climate Change?

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
We aspire to limit warming to 
1.5 
º
C


•
we must cut global emissions in 
half by 2030 
and be 
net zero by 
2050 
2.
To maintain stable human societies we must limit warming to 
2 
º
C
  
•
we must reduce global carbon emissions to
 net zero by 2050
The Paris COP-21 Climate Action Consensus Statement


Agreed Upon by Essentially Every Leader of Every Nation on Planet Earth

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/new-report-maps-out-the-u-s-road-to-net-zero-emissions/?fbclid=IwAR3C0Yrxo_4Obb2gS9mBBY-54CYCd3xKCDTl-TGQFF06_hyJjJJG7rmwxKs
National Academy of Science 
2021 Report: 
Outlines Pathway to Net Zero Emissions
Policies to get the US to net zero 
emission would produce a cleaner 
energy system, high-quality jobs and 
improve international competitiveness


The report warns, however, that this 
will require heavy political lifting by 
Congress and future administrations.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
This Special Generation...
1.
Every so often a generation is called upon to do something extraordinary.  


• In 1940 a generation was asked to rise up and fight a world war. 
• This generation is now being asked to rise up to an even greater challenge and 
decarbonize the global energy system and save all of humanity. 
2.
We can be small and shrink back and say it is too complex or it will cost too 
much or we can seize this moment to be truly great. 


3.
It really is a matter of now or never - and all of it has to take place within the 
next two decades!

© 2023 Bruce Monger

.

a path for achieving a 1.5 ºC limit.

It began with Cornell 
students camping out in 
front of Day Hall
 
demanding 
that the President commit to 
leading Cornell toward a 
better world!
Cornell 
Plans
 for Carbon Neutrality By 2035
All of this great stuff Cornell is doing about carbon neutrality 
Began With 
YOU!

© 2023 Bruce Monger
“I would found an institution where 
any person
 can find 
instruction in any study.” 
Ezra Cornell
The 2035 Climate Action Plan continues a 
longstanding Cornell tradition of recognizing 
the 
socially just thing to do
 well before 
other universities — 
and then acting on it!
Cornell defines itself in its motto as the Social 
Justus Ivy League School

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Concluding Remarks...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Coming Years Will Test Us All


Both Collectively and Individually
These times will test our courage and our integrity — 
we have been given a great 
opportunity to be heroic
 
Of all the generations that have ever existed on this earth, it falls on this one 
generation to decide if we cross the 1.5 
º
C or 2.0 
º
C warming thresholds. 
If we succeed in decarbonizing the global energy system by mid-century, our 
generation will be celebrated by future generations for next 10,000 years!  
Monuments will be built and epic poems will be written in celebration of this 
generation that saved humanity!

© 2023 Bruce Monger
This generation is called upon 
today to raise our collective voice 
and push to decarbonize the 
global energy system by 2050. 
Every So Often a Generation is 
Called Upon to Do Something 
Extraordinary...
I Dare You All to be Heroic!
